title: Enhancing Pixel Panic and webpage user experience (UX)
content:
In this latest update, I focused on significantly improving both the Pixel Panic game and my personal profile webpage.

For the webpage, I enhanced the overall look by refining the layout to be more visually appealing and ensuring it is responsive to user interactions such as hovers and clicks. I also enriched the site content by adding images showcasing the game, established a blog section where I began publishing regular development updates, and created an image gallery to better present the game's features.

Regarding Pixel Panic, I implemented a scoring system allowing players to earn points by catching stars, which adds a rewarding dynamic to the gameplay. The game's visuals were upgraded with new icons and a more vibrant color scheme, giving it a polished, engaging appearance. A lot of debugging went into fine-tuning the logic, especially to accurately detect when players catch stars to score points, ensuring a smooth and bug-free player experience.

Despite these advancements, some planned features, specifically on the webpage remain incomplete due to limited development time, notably the integration of an AI agent to bring advanced interactions and functionalities. I aim to revisit these in future updates.

title: Improving Pixel Panic and deploying the webpage!
content:
This blog post discusses the steps and ideas behind refining the core gameplay of Pixel Panic, enhancing both challenge and fun.

I played around a lot with the logic for the "pixels" in the game play, specifically how frequently they appear and how to deduct lives when collision happens!

I also spent a fair bit of time researching how to deploy my webpage, as I still haven't figure out how to do that on GitHub website.

title: Fetching data with HTML, CSS and vanilla JavaScript
content:
For the last few days, I have been exploring techniques on how to fetch and integrate data into a webpage using only HTML, CSS, and native JavaScript, without relying on any frameworks.

In short I haven't been very successful!

So, for now, the planned "search events" and prompt based AI searching that i wanted to integrate into the webpage, is non-functional.

title: Creating the game and webpage
content:
This initial blog chronicles the journey of beginning the Pixel Panic game development and setting up the corresponding webpage.

I have been doign the suggested projects on freeCodeCamp and also doing challenges on Codeware, but starting from scratch for the webpage and the game was very hard!

Started the webpage by playing around with the styling, but content was all over the place!
